required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Two Methods of Immunization for Intramuscular Injections
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Two Methods of Immunization for Intramuscular Injections

oversight_info.authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

brief_summary.textblock: This study is designed to compare two different styles of intramuscular injection (Bunch versus Z-Track)during flu vaccination with the following outcome measures as basis for comparison: perceive pain, redness, medication leakage, other complications within 72 hours in healthy adult volunteer subjects.

detailed_description.textblock: This study is designed to compare two different styles of intramuscular injection (Bunch versus Z-Track)during flu vaccination with the following outcome measures as basis for comparison: perceive pain, redness, medication leakage, other complications within 72 hours in healthy adult volunteer subjects.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Health Services Research

primary_outcome.description: Subjects will be asked to rate perceived pain on scale of 0-10

secondary_outcome.description: Any medication leakage from either arm within 72 hours
Redness, as determined by naive observer at injection site immediately and up to 72 hours after study.

arm_group.description: Subject receives Intramuscular injection by z-track method during flu vaccination given by employee health Registered Nurse into deltoid muscle.
Subject receives Intramuscular injection by bunch method during flu vaccination given by employee health Registered Nurse into deltoid muscle.

intervention.description: Subject receives immunization by bunch method.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- healthy adults without latex allergy over 18 years of age
Exclusion Criteria:
- latex allergy
- illness
- 18 years or less

overall_official.last_name: Lynn E Bayne, PhD, ARNP, NNP-BC

contact.last_name: Lynn E. Bayne, PhD, ARNP, NNP-BC

investigator.last_name: Lynn E Bayne, PhD, ARNP, NNP-BC
